title: George Duckworth
text:
George Duckworth (9 May 1901 – 5 January 1966) was a professional <a href="cricket">cricket</a>er who played <a href="first-class%20cricket">first-class cricket</a> for <a href="Lancashire%20County%20Cricket%20Club">Lancashire</a> and <a href="English%20cricket%20team">England</a>.
Duckworth, who won his cricketing fame as a <a href="wicket-keeper">wicket-keeper</a>, was born and died in <a href="Warrington">Warrington</a>, <a href="Lancashire">Lancashire</a>, and joined Lancashire in 1922. He played his first game for the county in 1923 and his last in 1938 and went on to become a member of the Lancashire committee. 1928 was his best season, with him taking 77 catches and 30 stumpings, and this earned him the accolade of being one of the <a href="Wisden%20Cricketers%20of%20the%20Year">Wisden Cricketers of the Year</a> in 1929. He played 24 <a href="Test%20cricket">Test match</a>es for England, but as a wicket-keeper he was in direct competition in his later years with <a href="Les%20Ames">Les Ames</a>, who was a much better batsman. He was awarded a benefit in 1934, which raised £1,257. He was reputed to have the loudest shout of appeal of any cricketer of his time.
Duckworth's total of 925 dismissals for Lancashire is a record for the county.
After retirement, Duckworth was a journalist and a broadcaster on both cricket and <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a>. He also acted as a cricket tour organiser and as baggage master and scorer on <a href="Marylebone%20Cricket%20Club">Marylebone Cricket Club</a> (MCC) tours.
A peanut shaped roundabout in his home town Warrington has been named after him. Duckworth's Roundabout is at Birchwood Way (A574) and Oakwood Gate.
Duckworth was the nephew of the rugby league footballer for <a href="Warrington%20Wolves">Warrington</a>, <a href="Jack%20Duckworth%20%28rugby%20league%29">Jack Duckworth</a>.
